AIRCZ Type:: Gatwick Airport Wind Turbine Consultation Zone:Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Gatwick Airport Limited, 7th Floor Destinations Place, London Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH06 0NP

AIRCZ Type:: Heathrow Planning Consultation Zone: All buildings, structures, erections and works exceeding 90 metres in height (295.3 feet)Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Heathrow Airport Limited, c/o Planning Services, First Point, Buckingham Gate, Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH6 0NT

application_details.scheme_name: Development Land Rear Of 27 To 29 St James Road

decision_conditions: All planting, seeding or turfing detailed in the approved landscape scheme shall be carried out in the first planting and seeding seasons following the occupation of the buildings or the completion of the development, whichever is the sooner; and any trees or plants which, within a period of 5 years from the completion of the development die, are removed or become seriously damaged or diseased shall be replaced in the next planting season with others of similar size and species, unless the Local Planning Authority gives written consent to any variation. The area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.Reason: To ensure that these works are properly implemented and maintained and in the interest of visual amenity in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to occupation, details of secure cycle parking facilities for the occupants of the development hereby approved have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site and building works required to implement the development shall be only carried out between the hours of 08.00 and 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 and 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays.Reason:  To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining residential occupiers in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Any flat roofed area shall not be converted or used as a balcony or sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason:  To protect the amenities and privacy of adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy, Adopted April 2012.

Within 3 months of first occupation, evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby permitted has achieved no less than the C02 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes Level 4.  Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 and WAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide.  Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day must be submitted to the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.Reason:  In order to ensure that all development is designed and built to make the most efficient use of resources, reduce its lifecycle impact on the environment and contributes to climate change mitigation and adaptation in accordance with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development shall take place until details of the implementation, adoption, maintenance and management of a sustainable drainage system have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.  The system shall be implemented prior to occupation and thereafter managed and maintained in accordance with the approved details.  Those details shall include a timetable for its implementation, and a management and maintenance plan for the lifetime of the development which shall include the arrangements for adoption by any public body or statutory undertaker, or any other arrangements to secure the effective operation of the sustainable drainage system throughout its lifetime.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and to prevent the increased risk of flooding in accordance with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the Local Development Framework Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
The development hereby permitted shall be commenced within 3 years from the date of this decision.Reason: In order to comply with Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1990 (as amended).

The development shall be completed in accordance with samples for all facing materials including fenestration which shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before any works on site are commenced. The development shall then be built in accordance with these approved samples and completed prior to occupation.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the details shown on the approved plans additional architectural detailing plans at scale 1:10 showing the windows, doors, overhangs, rainwater goods and their associated reveals and their relationship with the walls/fascias shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before any development is commenced on site.  The development shall be constructed in accordance with the approved details.Reason:  These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No flues or pipework shall be fixed to the elevations other than those shown on the drawings hereby approved or in accordance with details which shall have first been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: In the interests of the visual amenities of the area in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No fans, louvres, ducts, external lighting or other external plant other than those shown on the drawings hereby approved shall be installed without the prior written approval of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the occupiers of the neighbouring properties and the visual amenities of the area in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the walls of the building hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Before any occupation of the development hereby permitted, the first floor 'family bathroom' window in the south-western side elevation shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable.  Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing of a patterned type only which shall thereafter be retained as such. Obscure glazed windows should be obscured to minimum of level 3 on the Pilkington Scale. The use of any type of film or material affixed to clear glass is not acceptable for the purposes of this Condition.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any above ground works of the development hereby permitted, the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved details shall be implemented prior to the occupation of the development and retained as such for the life of the development. (a)  boundary treatment, including walls, fences and gates (including their manufacturer's specification, colour and texture).Reason: To ensure visual amenity and a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

All works on site shall take place in accordance with the following details which shall have previously been submitted to in the form of a Construction Management Plan and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to the commencement of work:  (a)  Provision for loading/unloading materials;(b)  Temporary site access;(c)  Signing system for works traffic;(d)  Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;(e)  Means of enclosure of the site;(f)  Wheel washing equipment;(g)  The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors;(h)  The erection and maintenance of security hoarding;(i)   Measures for the protection of surrounding trees; and,(j)  Construction hours.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The levels of buildings, roads, parking areas and pathways within the site shall only be in accordance with details which shall have previously been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before development is commenced.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and to ensure that the appearance and functioning of the development is satisfactory and to safeguard the amenities of adjoining occupiers in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012

Prior to the commencement of any above ground works of the development hereby permitted, the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved details shall be implemented prior to the occupation of the development and retained as such for the life of the development. (a)  waste and recycling storage facilities (materials, design and dimensions)Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to ensure visual amenity and a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any above ground works of the development hereby permitted, a landscaping scheme including details of 1 replacement tree shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority.  Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.  Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and in the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details for condition 34 (Acoustic Report) of planning permission  22/01658/FUL  have been assessed and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details.

----Officer Report ----The application site is located on the south side of Jubilee Way.The surrounding area is mixed in use. The site is located adjavcent the Metrpolitan Open Land of Tolworth Court Farm and King George Playing Fields.The application seeks to determine whether the prior approval of the Local Planning Authority is required for the siting and appearance of the installation of 20 metre high slimline monopole supporting 6no. antennas, the installation of 2no. equipment cabinets along with associated ancillary development thereto.The application has been assessed against the provisions of Schedule 2 Part 16 of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 as amended. The application has also been assessed against the policies of the National Planning Policy Framework and the current Development Plan policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy.The National Planning Policy Framework 2021 is clear at paragraph 118 in as much as the Local Planning Authority should not question need. Local planning authorities must determine applications on planning grounds only. They should not seek to prevent competition between different operators, question the need for an electronic communications system, or set health safeguards different from the International Commission guidelines for public exposure.This application is for prior approval, not for planning permission. Prior approval is a light-touch process which applies where the principle of the development has already been established (National Planning Practice Guidance) (Paragraph: 028 Reference ID: 13-028-20140306).Prior approval means that a developer has to seek approval from the local planning authority that specified elements of the development are acceptable before work can proceed. The matters for prior approval vary depending on the type of development and these are set out in full in the relevant parts in Schedule 2 to the General Permitted Development Order. A local planning authority cannot consider any other matters when determining a prior approval application (National Planning Practice Guidance) (Paragraph: 026 Reference ID: 13-026-20140306).The main considerations of the case are:- Siting and;- AppearanceThe application is located on the pavement in a prominant location on the south side of Jubilee Way near to the Industrial estate to the west and adjacent to designated Metropolitan Open Lands of Tolworth Court Farm and King George Playing Fields.The proposed mast would be 20m in height which would be in excess of 10 to 12m higher than a standard telegraph pole (8m) and street lamp column (10m) which are typical of other such predominant perpendicular pieces of street furniture found in the locality and it is considered that the siting and appearance would not be appropriate for this location by virtue of its siting and appearance which would result in an incongruous addition to the streetscene that would be visually intrusive and create visual clutter and would not be in keeping with and detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area and the setting of the adjacent Metropolitan Open Lands of Toworth Court Farm and King George Playing Fields and be in conflict with policies CS8, DM5 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.The need for an upgraded, modern telecommunications network is both acknowledged and appreciated, and indeed is given great weight in the decision making process; however, for the reasons cited above it is considered that the harm caused by the proposed installation would outweigh the benefits.In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way. We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises an end of terrace dwelling.Proposal Formation of dropped kerb. ConsultationsNine neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.RBK Neighbourhood Engineer - No objection The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- The impact of the proposal on the highwayCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Given that numerous properties on Chantry Road benefit from dropped kerb access and hardstandings to the front of their properties, it is considered that the proposal would be in-keeping within the immediate context of the site. As a result, the proposed development would not detract from the character and appearance of the street scene or the surrounding area, in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Council's adopted LFD Core Strategy.It is noted that the hardstanding has been installed. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  Due to its minor nature, it is considered that the proposals would not cause undue harm to the amenity of the neighbouring occupiers. The proposal would therefore be compliant with Policy DM10 of the Council's adopted LFD Core Strategy.HighwaysParagraph 111 of the NPPF is clear that: Development should only be prevented or refused on highways grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or the residual cumulative impacts on the road network would be severe.Local Policy DM10 requires new developments to have regard to highway safety and ensure they are not adversely affected. It is noted that the Council's Neighbourhood Engineer raised no objections to the scheme. The proposed new dropped kerb would be sited on a befitting location and would be easily visible by the highway users of Chantry Road. As such, it is considered that the proposal would not undermine the existing highway safety conditions of Chantry Road. In conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2016) Policies CS8, DM9 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

If you have evidence to contradict the local planning authority's assessment of the application, you are encouraged to apply for the development again and include that evidence in support of the application.

B.2 (c) states that any window inserted on a wall or roof slope forming a side elevation of the dwellinghouse must be—(i) obscure-glazed, and(ii) non-opening unless the parts of the window which can be opened are more than 1.7 metres above the floor of the room in which the window is installed.It has not been demonstrated on the plans or application form that these requirements have been met.

Application SiteThe application site is located on the northern side of Warren Drive North at the junction with Beresford Avenue. The building is not statutory or locally listed and is not located within a conservation area.ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for the installation of 1no. side roof light and addition of 1no. side window at first floor level.Consultation7no. properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact on the character and appearance of the area; and - Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposals involve the installation of 1no. rooflights to the side roofslope, together with the addition of 1no. window to the first floor side elevation. The proposed rooflight would be an aluminium Velux window flush to the roof. The window to the first floow side elevation is labelled on the submitted plans as obscure-glazed, and officers apply a condition to this effect.The proposed changes are considered acceptable in terms of their design and would result in minimal impact on the character and appearance of the host dwellinghouse and wider streetscene.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionThe proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area. Having regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.

The site comprises a mid-terrace dwelling.6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representation has been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey infill rear extension would be in general keeping with the Council's Residential Design SPD, Policy Guidance 33, therefore, it is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design and there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities. Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: Although the applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy and proposed plans which include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point, it does not sufficiently address the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The applicant is informed that Planning Condition 3 (Materials) of Planning Permission ref: 21/02481/FUL) is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

The applicant is informed that Planning Condition 19 (Vehicular Access) of Planning Permission ref: 21/02481/FUL) is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

Application SiteThe site comprises a ground floor shop and relates particularly to the shop front.Consultation16 Neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.RBK Neighbourhood Engineer - No objectionAssessmentThe application relates to the display of advertisements and not to any proposed amendments to the shop front itself. The main considerations are;-Amenity-Public safetyAmenity:The proposed advertisements would be proportional in size to the facade.  The advertisements would not create visual clutter and would not detract from the character and appearance of the host building or the surrounding area. The proposed advert would be non illuminated so would not lead to any significant light pollution.The proposal would accord with policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy.Public safetyThe proposed advertisements would not obscure any highway signs and would not conflict with or impede the free-flow of pedestrian or vehicular movement or create a distraction to highway users. As such the proposal would not prejudice highway safety.The proposal would accord with policy DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details for  Condition 13 (Nature Conservation) and 14 (Landscaping Scheme) of planning permission 22/02264/FUL (Application under Section 73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 to carry out development without compliance with Condition 1 (Approved Plans) of Planning Permission ref: 21/04028/FUL (Demolition of 6 no.x existing garages, and erection of 4Bed. 6P sustainable dwelling) is hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

Conditions 3 (Samples) of planning permisssion 21/01831/FUL- The details have been reviewed. The condition requires the submission of samples and the applicant has not submitted any. The applicant has submitted a document detailing the proposed materials however it is considered that their is insufficient detail to determine that their would be a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development. Condition 4 (Detailed Drawings) of planning permisssion 21/01831/FUL - The details have been reviewed and found to be acceptable.

The site comprises semi-detached dwelling.12 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.Relevant Planning History22/01191/HOU - Erection of first-floor rear extension and two-storey side extension with associated changes to fenestration - Refused on 01.06.2022The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. - Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment:  The applicant has omitted the two storey side extension previously submitted in the refused planning application: 22/01191/HOU and the first floor rear extension has also been reduced in depth. The revised proposed first floor side extension would have a total depth of 4.5m, it would main the existing gap between neighbouring property No. 55 Northcote Road and would not extend past the two storey rear extension of neighbouring property No.59 Northcote Road. Whilst it is noted that the proposed eternit cedral waterboarding would not have similarity to the host dwelling walls, officers note that the proposed development would generally be designed to respect the character of the original dwelling with the proposed pitched roof, as such would appear as a subordinate and appropriate addition to the host property. Officers consider that on balance there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development and would be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: As mentioned above, the proposed first floor side extension would have a total depth of 4.5m, it would main the existing gap between neighbouring property No. 55 Northcote Road and would not extend past the two storey rear extension of neighbouring property No.59 Northcote Road. Officers also acknowledge that 59 Northcote Road, has a roolight feature on the single storey rear extension which would be affected by the proposed development, however, officers note that space/room (kitchen/dinner) in which that rooflight serves, has windows which also provide sunlight and daylight. officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, '45 Degree Rule' and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities.Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed by the Borough Environmental Health Officer and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 19 (Management of Land Contamination) of planning permission 19/00330/FUL, which states:Condition 19 (Management of Land Contamination) - No development shall take place until an investigation and risk assessment, in addition to any assessment provided with the planning application, and has been completed in accordance with a scheme to assess the nature and extent of any contamination on the site, whether or not it originates on the site. The contents of the scheme should be submitted to and be approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The investigation and risk assessment must be undertaken by competent persons and a written report of the findings must be produced. The written report is subject to the approval in writing of the Local Planning Authority. The report of the findings must include:(i) a survey of the extent, scale and nature of contamination; (ii) an assessment of the potential risks to:o human health,o property (existing or proposed) including buildings, crops, livestock, pets, woodland and service lines and pipes,o adjoining land,o groundwaters and surface waters,o ecological systems,o archaeological sites and ancient monuments;(iii) an appraisal of remedial options, and proposal of the preferred option(s).This must be conducted in accordance with DEFRA and the Environment Agency's 'Model Procedures for the Management of Land Contamination, CLR 11.Reason: To ensure that risks from land contamination is understood prior to works on site both during the construction phase to the future users of the land and neighbouring land are minimised, together with those to controlled waters, property and ecological systems, and to ensure that the development can be carried out safely without unacceptable risks to workers, neighbours and other offsite receptors in accordance with Policies DM10.

Condition 4 (internal and external lighting strategy) - Information submitted was assessed by RBK Lighting Engineer and RBK design Officer. Both are satisfied that following a few amendments that the scheme is now compliant and this condition can now be approved.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that Part 11 of Condition 4 (internal and external lighting strategy) of planning application 19/01212/LBC is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.
For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Erection of a single storey rear extension. Piggy back roof extension and installation of 5nos side rooflights. Increase in roof height.'

We have received the email for a fast track service. Please complete the attached 'fast track proforma form' and pay the required amount as shown in the form. The fee required for your pre-planning application is £2,100.  Payment can be made online via the Kingston council website, via our Contact Centre on 020 8547 5002, or by cheque made payable to Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames.
Please submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 or 1:2500.

Please provide a Proposed Block Plan drawn at an identified standard metric scale (such as 1:200 or 1:500) showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site. The Block Plan must show the direction of North and should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.
The submitted proposed ground floor plan has new entrance gate, please clarify the proposal includes erection of entrance gate or not. Please submit the documents (Elevation) of entrance gate.
Please submit the elevations or details of heat pump.

For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Refurbishment works including fenestration alteration and cladding to front and rear elevations. New roofing to main house incorporating insulation. Installation of solar panels and enlargement of rooflights in top flat roof. Erection of single storey rear garden studio with green roof. Installation of heat pump to front garden.'If you do not agree or there are any changes, please amend it in your own words.

The proposed elevations do not show roof extension, whereas the proposed plan has roof extension for loft conversion, please amend the proposed elevations and proposed floor plans with the correct information.
